comment: Initial notes of apple. Sweet and bright blend. There is not much burn. added a drop of water and the texture turned buttery, bordering on oily. It was not as sweet. Added one ice cube to cool it down and it was better than with just water, but my favorite taste was neat, no water.

SF craft spirits festival 2018

Light nose, sweet
A very well-balanced blended scotch!  Citrus, toffee, and smoked creme brulee notes are prominent on the palate. Very enjoyable!
Not as smooth as I expected. It is a $50 bottle of scotch though, so I can’t expect much. The Creme Brûlée notes are very strong which I liked. Wasn’t a huge fan of the finish though.
Very high grain taste. Don't enjoy, tastes like a very cheap, young, blend.
Mild on nose, pale golden hue in color. Nose has hints of orange peel. A sip Starts off with honey followed by fruity pear honeysuckle with a mild burn at the end and a flat finish and no peat
Sweet citrus on the nose with vanilla. The taste is mild with more smoke than expected. Finish is medium in length with grain notes and a touch of spice.
Quick Hit: Heather, honey, lemon, hay. Soft velvet texture with sweet tea, honey, cloves and vanilla. Lemon oil finish with white pepper and oak.
Nose Is reminiscent of Glengoyne 12, citrusy palate with a pleasant finish

Very simple straight forward dram. Very one note on the nose creamy cereal grain and light sherry. Palate is creamy barley and one note Speyside sherry that swells and fades quickly  into a very mild Highland honeysuckle and salty? blend of Speyside Highland and Islay. A good beginner whisky.

Initial aroma is loaded with vanilla and caramel. Very faint whisper of smoke. A touch of water opens that up, but ice dulls it.
Tasted neat, it is very well balanced. Light in body, and a very smooth, creamy finish. Adding water doesn't change it much, but one square of ice highlighted the smoke and brine. The smoke builds as I get closer to the end of the glass, but never gets intense. Nice easy drinking whisky.
